{{for|the baseball player|Ryan Bradley (baseball)}} {{Infobox figure skater |name= Ryan Bradley |image= Ryan Bradley - 2006 Skate America 2.jpg |caption= Bradley at the [[2006 Skate America]] |country= [[United States of America|United States]] |birth_date= {{birth date and age|1983|11|17}} |birth_place= [[Saint Joseph, Missouri]] |residence = [[Colorado Springs, Colorado]] |height= {{convert|1.80|m|ftin|0|abbr=on}} |formerpartner= [[Tiffany Vise]] |coach= [[Tom Zakrajsek]],
[[Becky Calvin]] |choroegrapher= [[Renee Roca]]
[[Catarina Lindgren]] |formerchoreographer= [[Nikolai Morozov (figure skater)|Nikolai Morozov]]
[[Braden Overett]] |skating club= [[Broadmoor SC]] |retired = May 10, 2011 |combined total= 212.75 |combined date= [[2008 Skate Canada]] |SP score= 72.50 |SP date= [[2008 Skate Canada]] |FS score= 140.25 |FS date= [[2008 Skate Canada]] }} '''Ryan Bradley''' (born November 17, 1983 in [[Saint Joseph, Missouri]]) is an [[United States|American]] [[figure skater]]. He is the 2011 [[United States Figure Skating Championships|U.S. champion]], 2007 [[United States Figure Skating Championships|U.S. silver medalist]] and three time U.S. Collegiate Champion. Bradley is known for his crowd-pleasing programs and [[backflips]]. == Biography == === Personal life === Bradley comes from a family of skaters.{{cite news | url = http://www.goldenskate.com/articles/2002/022503.shtml | title = Ryan Bradley: Bradley Continues Family Tradition | last = Mittan | first = Barry |date = February 25, 2003 | work = GoldenSkate.com | accessdate = December 22, 2010}} His sister, Becky, is a skating coach and former competitive skater, and his mother is a [[USFSA]] judge.{{cite news | url = http://www.goldenskate.com/articles/2002/071102.shtml | title = Ryan Bradley: Online Interview | last = | first = |date = July 11, 2002 | work = GoldenSkate.com | accessdate = December 22, 2010}} Bradley studies business at the [[University of Colorado at Colorado Springs]]. He is a volunteer at the [[Broadmoor Skating Club]] and a coach at the [[Colorado Springs World Arena]]. === Career === Ryan Bradley began skating at the age of two and participated in the U.S. Figure Skating Basic Skills program from 1986-1988.{{cite news | url = http://absoluteskating.com/interviews/2009ryanbradley.html | title = Ryan Bradley: "I get so much energy from the audience, from looking into their eyes and watching their emotions." | last = Vernon | first = Nadin |year = 2009 | work = AbsoluteSkating.com | accessdate = December 22, 2010}} From 1996-1998, Bradley competed in [[pair skating]] with [[Tiffany Vise]].{{cite web | title =Crystal Report Viewer | work =ISU.org | url=http://www.isufs.org/bios/isufs00003278.htm | accessdate =2007-04-01 }} They competed twice at the [[United States Figure Skating Championships|U.S. Championships]]. In 2001, he reached Sectionals with Melissa Gallegos. Bradley decided not to continue with pairs, preferring to focus on his singles career and not having enough time to train in both. As a single skater, he won the silver medal on the Intermediate level at the Junior Olympics (later renamed ''Junior Nationals'') in the 1994-1995 season. The 1995-1996 season was Bradley's first on the Novice level, and he did not make it out of Sectionals. In the 1996-1997 season, he placed 7th at the novice level at Nationals. In the 1997-1998 season, Bradley won the silver medal on the novice level at Nationals. This win earned him a trip to the [[Triglav Trophy]], which he won. The following season, 1998â1999, Bradley debuted on the [[1998â1999 ISU Junior Grand Prix|ISU Junior Grand Prix]]. He won medals at both his events. At that time, the [[World Junior Figure Skating Championships|World Junior Championships]] were held before the U.S. Championships. At the Junior Worlds selection competition, Bradley placed second and was placed on the team for the [[1999 World Junior Figure Skating Championships|1999 Junior Worlds]], where he placed 10th. At the [[1999 United States Figure Skating Championships|1999 U.S. Championships]], he won the Junior title. He competed at the [[Gardena Spring Trophy]] following Nationals and won the competition. In the 1999-2000 season, Bradley remained on the [[1999â2000 ISU Junior Grand Prix|Junior Grand Prix]] circuit. He won two more medals and qualified for the Junior Grand Prix Final, where he finished 8th. He went on to place 7th in his senior debut at the [[2000 United States Figure Skating Championships|2000 U.S. Championships]]. He went on to place 5th at the [[2000 World Junior Figure Skating Championships|2000 Junior Worlds]]. In the 2000-2001 season, Bradley won both of his [[2000â2001 ISU Junior Grand Prix|Junior Grand Prix]] events and made his senior international debut at the [[Golden Spin of Zagreb]], which he won. He placed 5th at the Junior Grand Prix Final. He placed 9th at the [[2001 United States Figure Skating Championships|2001 U.S. Championships]]. He was originally placed on the team for the [[2001 World Junior Figure Skating Championships|2001 Junior Worlds]]. However, he was forced to withdraw prior to the event with injury. He had surgery to repair damage to his landing knee. His vacated spot was given to [[Evan Lysacek]]. In the 2001-2002 season, [[U.S. Figure Skating]] did not allow American skaters to compete on the [[2001â2002 ISU Junior Grand Prix|Junior Grand Prix]] because of security concerns following the [[September 11, 2001 attacks]]. Bradley placed 7th at the [[2002 United States Figure Skating Championships|2002 U.S. Championships]]. He went on to the [[2002 World Junior Figure Skating Championships|2002 Junior Worlds]] and placed 15th. In the 2002-2003 season, Bradley competed at the Karl Schafer Memorial, placing 4th. He made his Grand Prix debut at the [[2003 Skate Canada International]], where he placed 6th. He was 9th at the [[2003 United States Figure Skating Championships|2003 U.S. Championships]]. In the 2003-2004 season, he placed 6th at the [[2004 United States Figure Skating Championships|2004 U.S. Championships]]. He made his senior ISU Championship debut at the [[2004 Four Continents Figure Skating Championships|2004 Four Continents]], where he placed 11th. Bradley missed most of the 2004-2005 season after breaking his arm while playing dodge ball; he had a spiral fracture in the humerus of his right arm and was off the ice for six months.{{cite news | url = http://www.skatetoday.com/2007/03/26/from-bad-breaks-to-a-breakout-for-bradley/ | title = From Bad Breaks to a Breakout for Bradley | last = Mittan | first = Barry | date = March 26, 2007 | publisher = SkateToday | accessdate = August 8, 2011}} He competed in the 2005-2006 season, hoping to contend for a spot to the [[2006 Winter Olympics]]. He placed 8th at the [[2006 United States Figure Skating Championships|2006 U.S. Championships]]. [[Image:Ryan Bradley Backflip - 2006 Skate America.jpg|thumb|right|Bradley performing a backflip in exhibition at the 2006 Skate America]] In the 2006-2007 season, Bradley was given a host invitation to the [[2006 Skate America]] due to the retirement of skaters who had placed ahead of him at the 2006 Nationals. Bradley placed 8th. Bradley accidentally cut his shin with his blade three weeks before the [[2007 United States Figure Skating Championships|2007 U.S. Championships]]. At the event, he held 3rd place after the short program. He skated last in the free skate, and won the silver medal, ahead of defending champion [[Johnny Weir]]. Upon learning that he had won the silver, Bradley skated back onto the ice and performed a backflip for the crowd. Bradley went on to the [[2007 Four Continents Figure Skating Championships|2007 Four Continents]], held at his home rink, the World Arena in Colorado Springs, Colorado, where he placed fourth behind training-mate [[Jeremy Abbott]]. During the off-season, he dealt with a torn meniscus in his right knee. In the 2007-2008 season, Bradley competed on the Grand Prix circuit with a 6th place finish at [[2007 Skate America|Skate America]] and a 5th at [[2007 Trophee Eric Bompard|Trophee Eric Bompard]]. He finished 5th at the [[2008 United States Figure Skating Championships|2008 U.S. Championships]]. Bradley began the 2008-2009 season at the [[2008 Skate Canada International]], where he won the silver medal. He then placed 7th at [[2008 TrophÃ©e Eric Bompard]]. At the [[2009 United States Figure Skating Championships|2009 U.S. Championships]] Bradley finished 4th. He was added to the U.S. team to the [[2010 World Figure Skating Championships|2010 World Championships]] after [[Evan Lysacek]] withdrew.{{cite news | url = http://web.icenetwork.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20100318&content_id=8827414&vkey=ice_news | title = Broken foot and all, Bradley determined to compete | last = Rosewater | first = Amy |date = March 18, 2010 | work = IceNetwork | accessdate = June 16, 2011 }} Before the event, Bradley broke the fifth metatarsal in his left foot but was cleared to compete. He finished 18th. Bradley was initially planning to retire from competitive skating but decided to resume training in mid-October.{{cite news | url = http://newsblogs.chicagotribune.com/sports_globetrotting/2011/04/bradley-time-catastrophe-world-championships-figure-skating.html | title = Under horrible circumstances, Bradley gains needed time before figure skating worlds | last = Hersh | first = Philip |date = April 20, 2011 | work = [[The Chicago Tribune]] | accessdate = April 21, 2011 }} He missed the Grand Prix season but competed at the [[2011 United States Figure Skating Championships|2011 U.S. Championships]]. Bradley won the short program and placed fourth in the free skate to win the overall competition and become the US National Champion for the first time in his career. He was selected to compete at the [[2011 World Figure Skating Championships|2011 World Championships]].{{cite news | url = http://www.universalsports.com/news/article/newsid=528368.html | title = Happiness equals success for Bradley | first =Alexa | last =Ainsworth |date = April 6, 2011 | work = | publisher =UniversalSports.com | accessdate = April 6, 2011}}{{cite news | url = http://absoluteskating.com/index.php?cat=interviews&id=2011bradley | title = Ryan Bradley: "I have found inner peace with my skating" | last = Golinsky | first = Reut |date = April 21, 2011 | work = Absolute Skating | accessdate = April 21, 2011 }} On May 10, 2011, Bradley announced his retirement from competitive skating.{{cite news | url = http://www.usfsa.org/Story.asp?id=46136&type=media | title = 2011 U.S. Champion Ryan Bradley Announces Retirement from Competitive Figure Skating | last = | first = |date = May 10, 2011 | publisher = [[U.S. Figure Skating]] | accessdate = June 7, 2011 }} He was coached by Tom Zakrajsek for 22 years.{{cite news | url = http://web.icenetwork.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20110630&content_id=21206080&vkey=ice_news | title = The Inside Edge with Sarah and Drew - June 30 | first = Sarah S. | last = Brannen | first2 = Drew | last2 = Meekins | date = June 30, 2011 | accessdate = June 30, 2011 | publisher = icenetwork }} == Commercials and endorsements == Bradley appeared in a commercial for [[Fuji Xerox]] with [[StÃ©phane Lambiel]], wearing heavy makeup to appear as an old man. He performed a backflip in this commercial. Due to its popularity, Fuji released a second one explaining how it was done. == Programs == [[File:2011 World Championships Ryan BRADLEY.jpg|thumb|right|Bradley performs during the short program at the 2011 World Championships]] {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- !Season !Short program !Free skating !Exhibition |- ! 2010â2011 | [[Boogie Woogie Bugle Boy]] | [[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart|Amadeus - Mozart]] Medley | [[Willy Wonka & the Chocolate Factory|Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory]] |- ! 2009â2010 | [[Dark Eyes (song)|Dark Eyes]]
